ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I can use Super collider now.
good
I learned many of the different algorithms used by computers to compose music. I also got a really nice overview of the broad field of computer music.
This is a great course. It is extremely interesting and will teach you how to programming for music composition, which is something really unique and awesome.

I learned about the intersection between computers and algorithms with music. Specifically, I learned about the history of computer music, what computer music looks like now, and the direction it is taking in the future. I also learned how to code in SuperCollider, a digital audio synthesis platform.
I learned how to use Supercollider, the programming language and IDE for Computer Music creation.  I learned how to use different algorithms to make computer music.
SuperCollider

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The projects are great. I've never had so much flexibility in my Computer Science assignments before. Sometimes I would put in less or more effort than I should have, based on how interested I was in the assignment, which was a nice option to have for once.
good

This course gives a really nice overview of computer music, and each project taught me a new skill. I did feel like I was teaching myself a lot of the material for each project, but part of that might be inherent in the fact that it's a computer science class and you just need to figure out how to implement the things we discussed in class by yourself.

I think that the course is well organized, structured by algorithms. However, I felt that we could have been eased into SuperCollider better, as coding in it was quite confusing and hard to grasp (I am still pretty confused).

Strengths: nice professor
Weaknesses: bad documentation, unclear instructions, no feedback
It would probably be good for there to be either quizzes to incentivize paying more attention to lecture.

Getting to collaborate with people on projects was a huge strength in this course.  Not enough CS classes here allow collaboration on projects/psets, so that was definitely a plus.  Scott is also an awesome lecturer.  He's super engaging, leaves time for questions and feedback, and truly cares about students' well-being.  

Something that can be improved is making sure people have partners for projects (if they want one) before we start working on the project.  Sometimes it was really hard to find a partner for a project and I felt left behind.  I feel this can be rectified by allowing people to get into groups during class and having time to find other people who may not be in a group but want to be to find each other during the classes where the project is being introduced.
Lecture

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yeah, it's  CS elective that's on the lighter side and can be interesting at times. Best CS elective I've taken tbh.
yes, an interesting course

Yes, if they have a strong background in both music and computer science. Professor Petersen's reviews of music and computer science topics were both pretty brief, so it helps to be generally familiar with them going into the class. That being said, I learned a lot about how computers can be used to create music, and it was really fun combining logic and creativity.

I would recommend this course to any student with a background of music. If you are just looking for a CS elective and have no prior music experience/aren't interested in music, I can see the course being even more confusing.
If you want a relatively easy CS credit, have interest in music theory, avant-garde music and systems, yes.

Yes!  I think everyone in CS should take a course with Scott!  Be warned that you need really brush up/learn music theory beforehand/during the class and spend some time learning Supercollider on your own.  Otherwise, it was a very cool, enriching, and fun class!
Yes. Interesting topic
